title: How your muscular system works - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: How many muscles work together to lift your foot, propel it forward, and set it down when you take a step?
What are the three main types of muscles in the muscular system?
What is the primary function of the muscular system?

options.label: A
options.text: To circulate blood throughout the body

multiple-choice.question: Which type of muscle contraction creates a stabilizing force?

options.label: C
options.text: Muscle fibers that don't change in length

options.label: A
options.text: Fast-twitch fibers are stronger, while slow-twitch fibers are weaker

options.label: B
options.text: Fast-twitch fibers react quickly but tire easily, while slow-twitch fibers react slowly but last longer

options.label: C
options.text: Fast-twitch fibers are used for endurance activities, while slow-twitch fibers are used for sprinting

options.label: D
options.text: Fast-twitch fibers are used for posture, while slow-twitch fibers are used for movement

multiple-choice.question: Which type of muscle is responsible for pumping blood through the blood vessels?
What is the primary byproduct of muscle activity?
What percentage of body warmth is provided by muscle activity?

title: The strange case of the cyclops sheep - Tien Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: What was the unusual deformity observed in the lambs born to sheep in Idaho in the 1950s?

options.label: A
options.text: They were born with six legs.

options.label: B
options.text: They were born with one eye (cyclops).

options.label: C
options.text: They were born with no ears.

options.label: D
options.text: They were born with no tail.

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial hypothesis of the researchers regarding the cause of the deformity in the lambs?

options.label: A
options.text: The pregnant ewes had been exposed to radiation.

options.label: B
options.text: The pregnant ewes had snacked on poisonous, birth defect-causing plants.

options.label: C
options.text: The pregnant ewes had been infected with a virus.

options.label: D
options.text: The pregnant ewes had been exposed to pesticides.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name given to the active molecule found in the wild corn lilies that caused the deformity in the lambs?
What is the function of the hedgehog gene in animal development?

options.label: A
options.text: It tells cells to release a protein that inhibits cell growth.

options.label: B
options.text: It tells cells to release a protein that promotes cell growth.

options.label: C
options.text: It tells cells to release a protein that kicks off a complex series of cellular signals.

options.label: D
options.text: It tells cells to release a protein that stops cellular signals.

multiple-choice.question: How does cyclopamine interrupt the normal development pathway in animals?

options.label: A
options.text: It binds to the hedgehog protein and prevents it from functioning.

options.label: B
options.text: It binds to the patched protein and prevents it from functioning.

options.label: C
options.text: It binds to the smoothened protein and prevents it from signaling cells.

options.label: D
options.text: It binds to the cells and prevents them from receiving signals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the human syndrome associated with uncontrolled activation of the smoothened protein?
Why was cyclopamine not used as a treatment for cancers associated with Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: It was not effective in treating the cancers.

options.label: B
options.text: It caused negative side effects and had difficult chemical properties to work with.

options.label: C
options.text: It was too expensive to produce.

options.label: D
options.text: It was not approved by regulatory agencies.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the research on cyclopamine and its related molecules?

options.label: B
options.text: Two related molecules were approved as skin cancer medicines in 2012 and 2015.

options.label: C
options.text: Cyclopamine was approved as a skin cancer medicine.

options.label: D
options.text: The research was stopped due to lack of funding.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the patched protein in the hedgehog signaling pathway?

options.label: A
options.text: It inhibits the smoothened protein from signaling cells.

options.label: B
options.text: It activates the smoothened protein to signal cells.

options.label: C
options.text: It binds to the hedgehog protein and prevents it from functioning.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no role in the hedgehog signaling pathway.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the discovery of cyclopamine and its related molecules?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a better understanding of the hedgehog signaling pathway.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the development of effective treatments for cancers associated with Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome.

options.label: C
options.text: It showed that sometimes there's more than meets the eye in scientific research.

title: A brief history of banned numbers - Alessandra King

multiple-choice.question: What was considered mightier than the sword, according to the phrase mentioned in the transcript?
Why did the Pythagoreans consider irrational numbers a threat to their notion of a perfect universe?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were difficult to calculate

options.label: B
options.text: Because they couldn't be expressed by any combination of whole numbers or fractions

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were too complex to understand

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were not numerical patterns

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Hippasus, the Pythagorean who discovered irrational numbers?

options.label: A
options.text: He was praised for his discovery

options.label: B
options.text: He was exiled for publicizing his findings

options.label: C
options.text: He was drowned as punishment from the gods

options.label: D
options.text: Both B and C are correct

multiple-choice.question: Why were Hindu-Arabic numerals considered a threat to authorities in the Middle Ages?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were easier to forge or alter

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were less familiar to customers than to merchants

options.label: C
options.text: Because they included a symbol for zero, which opened the door to negative numbers and debt recording

multiple-choice.question: What city banned the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals for record keeping in the 13th century?
Why did some mathematicians, like Gerolamo Cardano, avoid using zero?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was not widely accepted

options.label: C
options.text: Because it would have made it easier to find solutions to cubic and quartic equations

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was not necessary for their calculations

multiple-choice.question: Why are some numbers banned or considered illegal today?

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the information they carry

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B are correct

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B is correct

multiple-choice.question: What type of information can be translated into a string of numbers?
What was the significance of the large prime number shared and distributed in 2001?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a code that could be used to decrypt DVDs

options.label: B
options.text: It was a code that could be used to encrypt DVDs

options.label: C
options.text: It was a random number with no significance

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the idea behind the concept of "illegal numbers"?

options.label: A
options.text: That numbers can be used to represent concepts and information

options.label: B
options.text: That numbers can be used to decrypt codes

options.label: C
options.text: That numbers can be used to encrypt codes

title: Are you a body with a mind or a mind with a body? - Maryam Alimardani

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the rubber hand illusion experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: To demonstrate the temporary nature of the mind-body connection.

options.label: B
options.text: To show how our senses can easily mislead us in our judgment of self.

options.label: C
options.text: To prove the existence of a non-physical consciousness.

options.label: D
options.text: To test the limits of human endurance.

multiple-choice.question: According to Ren√© Descartes, what is the ultimate proof of our existence?

options.label: A
options.text: The existence of a non-physical consciousness.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to think and have thoughts.

options.label: D
options.text: The existence of a material body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem that arises if we accept the idea of a non-physical mind?

options.label: A
options.text: How can the mind interact with the physical body?

options.label: B
options.text: How can the body exist without a mind?

options.label: C
options.text: How can we prove the existence of a non-physical mind?

options.label: D
options.text: How can we distinguish between the mind and body?

multiple-choice.question: What is the view of many modern scientists regarding the mind-body connection?

options.label: A
options.text: That the mind and body are separate entities.

options.label: B
options.text: That the mind is a non-physical entity that interacts with the body.

options.label: C
options.text: That there is no distinction between the mind and body.

options.label: D
options.text: That the body is a temporary shell for the mind.

multiple-choice.question: According to neuroscience, how is our mental development formed?

options.label: A
options.text: Through the interaction of our body with the external world.

options.label: B
options.text: Through the activity of our brain alone.

options.label: C
options.text: Through the presence of a non-physical consciousness.

options.label: D
options.text: Through the existence of a material body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the idea behind mind uploading?

options.label: A
options.text: Transferring human consciousness into a computer.

options.label: C
options.text: Developing neural prosthetics and wearable robots.

options.label: D
options.text: Simulating a body capable of delivering physical sensations.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the view of Buddhist thought and some philosophers regarding the mind-body connection?

options.label: A
options.text: That the mind and body are separate entities.

options.label: B
options.text: That the body is a temporary shell for the mind.

options.label: C
options.text: That the mind and body are deeply interconnected.

options.label: D
options.text: That the mind is a non-physical entity that interacts with the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the question that remains open regarding the mind-body connection?

options.label: B
options.text: How can the mind interact with the physical body?

options.label: C
options.text: Is the mind a non-physical entity?

options.label: D
options.text: Is the body a temporary shell for the mind?

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the possible implication of extending our sense of self to new wearable devices?

options.label: A
options.text: Our brains may eventually adapt to a restructured version with new sensory representations.

options.label: B
options.text: We may lose our sense of self.

options.label: C
options.text: We may become more aware of our physical body.

options.label: D
options.text: We may develop a non-physical consciousness.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main theme of the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: The existence of a non-physical consciousness.

options.label: D
options.text: The development of neuroscience and psychology.

title: Should we get rid of standardized testing? - Arlo Kempf

multiple-choice.question: Where were the first standardized tests administered?
What were the subjects included in the first standardized tests administered in China?
What is a percentile in the context of standardized tests?

options.label: A
options.text: A measure of a test-taker's score in relation to the average score

options.label: B
options.text: A measure of a test-taker's score in relation to the highest score

options.label: C
options.text: A measure of the percentage of test-takers who scored below a certain score

options.label: D
options.text: A measure of the percentage of test-takers who scored above a certain score

multiple-choice.question: What is the usefulness of a standardized test dependent on?

options.label: A
options.text: The job it is asked to do and the test-taker's ability

options.label: B
options.text: The job it is asked to do and its design

options.label: C
options.text: The test-taker's ability and the test's design

options.label: D
options.text: The test's design and the scoring system

multiple-choice.question: What may happen if a standardized test is given the wrong job or is not designed properly?

options.label: A
options.text: It may end up measuring the right things

options.label: B
options.text: It may end up measuring the wrong things

options.label: C
options.text: It may not be able to measure anything

options.label: D
options.text: It may be invalid but reliable

multiple-choice.question: What are some limitations of standardized tests?

options.label: A
options.text: They can only measure academic knowledge

options.label: B
options.text: They can only measure abstract characteristics

options.label: C
options.text: They can have trouble measuring abstract characteristics or skills such as creativity and critical thinking

options.label: D
options.text: They can only be used for evaluating students

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between reliability and validity in the context of standardized tests?

options.label: A
options.text: Reliability refers to the consistency of results, while validity refers to the accuracy of results

options.label: B
options.text: Reliability refers to the accuracy of results, while validity refers to the consistency of results

options.label: C
options.text: Reliability refers to the ability of a test to measure what it is supposed to measure, while validity refers to the consistency of results

options.label: D
options.text: Reliability refers to the consistency of results, while validity refers to the ability of a test to measure what it is supposed to measure

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a validity problem in a standardized test?

options.label: A
options.text: A test that consistently gives different results for the same test-taker

options.label: B
options.text: A test that consistently gives the same results for different test-takers

options.label: C
options.text: A test that measures something it is not supposed to measure

options.label: D
options.text: A test that is interpreted to mean something it does not

multiple-choice.question: What is a concern of many social scientists regarding standardized tests?

options.label: A
options.text: That they may lead to positive changes for test-takers

options.label: B
options.text: That they may lead to negative changes for test-takers

options.label: C
options.text: That they may not be able to measure anything

options.label: D
options.text: That they may be too easy

multiple-choice.question: Who is responsible for ensuring that standardized tests are used properly?

options.label: D
options.text: The users of the test results

title: How do executive orders work? - Christina Greer

multiple-choice.question: What is an executive order in the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: A law passed by Congress and signed by the President.

options.label: B
options.text: A presidential decree that requires Congressional approval.

options.label: C
options.text: An order issued by the President without consultation or permission from Congress.

options.label: D
options.text: A judicial review by the court system to determine the constitutionality of a law.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process for passing a law in the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: The President proposes a bill, which is then approved by Congress.

options.label: B
options.text: A member of Congress proposes a bill, which is then approved by a majority vote in Congress and signed by the President.

options.label: C
options.text: The President issues an executive order, which is then enforced by the court system.

options.label: D
options.text: The court system proposes a bill, which is then approved by Congress and signed by the President.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of judicial review in the context of executive orders?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure that executive orders are enforced by the court system.

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the constitutionality of executive orders and invalidate any that overreach the President's power.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide Congressional approval for executive orders.

options.label: D
options.text: To allow the President to issue executive orders without consultation or permission from Congress.

multiple-choice.question: When can a president use an executive order?

options.label: A
options.text: Only in times of crisis or emergency.

options.label: C
options.text: To exert power without working with Congress, or to respond to emergencies, or to direct agencies in the federal government.

options.label: D
options.text: Only to clarify and help implement a policy that needs to be easily defined.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a famous executive order that changed the course of American history?

options.label: A
options.text: FDR's executive order to establish the Works Progress Administration.

options.label: B
options.text: Harry Truman's executive order to desegregate the armed forces.

options.label: C
options.text: Lyndon Johnson's executive order to establish requirements for nondiscriminatory practices in hiring and employment.

multiple-choice.question: How many executive orders did FDR issue during his presidency?
What is the U.S. Constitution's stance on the extent of the President's power?

options.label: A
options.text: The Constitution clearly defines the President's power and limits.

options.label: B
options.text: The Constitution is somewhat ambiguous on the extent of the President's power.

options.label: C
options.text: The Constitution grants the President absolute power.

options.label: D
options.text: The Constitution limits the President's power to only issuing executive orders.

multiple-choice.question: What can Congress do to counteract an executive order?

options.label: A
options.text: Pass a law to counteract the executive order.

options.label: B
options.text: Issue a judicial review to determine the constitutionality of the executive order.

options.label: C
options.text: Approve the executive order through a majority vote.

options.label: D
options.text: Do nothing, as executive orders are absolute.

multiple-choice.question: What can judges do to halt an executive order?

options.label: B
options.text: Approve the executive order through a judicial review.

options.label: C
options.text: Pass a law to counteract the executive order.

options.label: D
options.text: Do nothing, as executive orders are absolute.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential impact of an executive order?

options.label: A
options.text: It can only have a minor impact on the country.

options.label: B
options.text: It can change the course of history, for better or for worse.

options.label: C
options.text: It can only be used to respond to emergencies.

options.label: D
options.text: It can only be used to direct agencies in the federal government.

title: What are gravitational waves? - Amber L. Stuver

multiple-choice.question: What was witnessed by scientists on September 14, 2015, for the first time in human history?

multiple-choice.question: How do gravitational waves move?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The location of the object that generated it

title: The myth of Cupid and Psyche - Brendan Pelsue

multiple-choice.question: Why was Psyche abandoned by her father on a rocky crag?

options.label: B
options.text: Because the Oracle of Apollo told him to, saying she would marry a cruel and savage serpent-like winged evil.

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: She asked Cupid for help, and he sorted the seeds for her.

options.label: C
options.text: An ant colony took pity on her and helped her with the work.

options.label: D
options.text: She used magic to sort the seeds.

multiple-choice.question: What was the second task that Venus gave to Psyche to complete before she could marry Cupid?

options.label: A
options.text: To bring her the fleece of the golden sheep.

options.label: B
options.text: To sort a huge, messy pile of seeds in a single night.

options.label: C
options.text: To travel to the Underworld and convince Proserpina to put a drop of her beauty in a box.

options.label: D
options.text: To bring her a bottle of water from the Fountain of Youth.

options.label: B
options.text: She asked Cupid for help, and he got the fleece for her.

options.label: C

options.label: A
options.text: To bring her the fleece of the golden sheep.

options.label: B
options.text: To sort a huge, messy pile of seeds in a single night.

options.text: To travel to the Underworld and convince Proserpina to put a drop of her beauty in a box.

title: The left brain vs. right brain myth - Elizabeth Waters

multiple-choice.question: What is the common myth about the human brain that is unsupported by scientific evidence?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain has a right and left side.

options.label: B
options.text: The left side of the brain controls movement and the right side controls sight.

options.label: C
options.text: The left side of the brain controls logic and the right side controls creativity.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain uses both sides to make a complete image of the world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference in the functions controlled by the left and right sides of the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: The left side controls logic and the right side controls creativity.

options.label: B
options.text: The left side controls movement and the right side controls sight.

options.label: C
options.text: The left side controls the motion of the left arm and leg, and the right side controls the motion of the right arm and leg.

options.label: D
options.text: The left side controls the right visual field and the right side controls the left visual field.

multiple-choice.question: Why do scientists think that the brain's left and right sides may have developed to control different body functions?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the brain's processing power.

options.label: B
options.text: To improve the brain's memory capacity.

options.label: C
options.text: To give animals a survival advantage by allowing for quicker reflexes.

options.label: D
options.text: To enable the brain to perform complex mathematical calculations.

multiple-choice.question: What was the finding of neurologists Broca and Wernicke when they examined patients with communication problems due to injuries?

options.label: A
options.text: The patients had damage to their right temporal lobes.

options.label: B
options.text: The patients had damage to their left temporal lobes.

options.label: C
options.text: The patients had damage to both their left and right temporal lobes.

options.label: D
options.text: The patients had no damage to their temporal lobes.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They showed a significant increase in attention abilities.

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the production of ATP

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is adenosine, and what is its role in the human body?

options.label: B
options.text: Adenosine is a molecule that helps us feel happy.

options.label: C
options.text: Adenosine is a molecule that induces sleepiness.

options.label: D
options.text: Adenosine is a molecule that increases energy production.

options.label: C
options.text: Caffeine increases the production of adenosine receptors.

options.label: D
options.text: Caffeine decreases the production of adenosine receptors.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between caffeine, adenosine, and dopamine?

options.label: A
options.text: Caffeine blocks adenosine, which increases dopamine production.

options.label: B
options.text: Caffeine blocks dopamine, which increases adenosine production.

options.label: C
options.text: Caffeine increases adenosine production, which decreases dopamine production.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.text: Increased risk of Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, and some types of cancer

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body when it adapts to regular caffeine consumption?

options.label: B
options.text: The body becomes less sensitive to caffeine.

title: How to spot a misleading graph - Lea Gaslowitz

multiple-choice.question: What is a common way that graphs can misrepresent data?

options.label: A
options.text: By using too many data points

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the technique of carefully choosing a time range to exclude the impact of a major event?

options.label: A
options.text: The graph may be using too many data points

options.label: B
options.text: The graph may be distorting the scale

options.label: C
options.text: The graph may not be accounting for population growth

options.label: D
options.text: The graph may be using too many colors

options.label: A
options.text: Because the graph may be using too many data points

options.label: B
options.text: Because the graph may be distorting the scale

options.label: C
options.text: Because a small change in value can have a significant impact

options.label: D
options.text: Because the graph may be using too many colors

options.label: A
options.text: Look at the labels, numbers, scale, and context

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Take the graph at face value

options.label: D
options.text: Try to recreate the graph yourself

options.label: B
options.text: A graph showing the average annual ocean temperature from 1880 to 2016

options.label: C
options.text: A graph showing the rise in American unemployment from 2008 to 2010

options.label: D
options.text: A graph showing the reliability of Chevy trucks

options.label: A
options.text: Because the graph may be using too many data points

options.label: B
options.text: Because the graph may be distorting the scale

options.label: C
options.text: Because the graph may not be accounting for relevant data

options.label: D
options.text: Because the graph may be trying to tell a specific story

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how a graph can be misleading if it distorts the scale?

options.label: A
options.text: A graph showing the number of people watching the Super Bowl each year

options.label: B
options.text: A graph showing the average annual ocean temperature from 1880 to 2016

options.label: C
options.text: A graph showing the rise in American unemployment from 2008 to 2010

options.label: D
options.text: A graph showing the reliability of Chevy trucks

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Graphs are always a reliable way to present data

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
